text: This is killing me... :(  I took my girlfriend to see this film in November/Dec when it came out.  It moved me in *so* many different ways.  She had been suffering from Anxiety... Depression... BPD... OCD--most all of her life.  And I'd been BEGGING for her to get help, as... it was starting to take a toll on me... on us.  In January... she asked if I wanted to see it again.  I was OVERJOYED.  We went.  I cried again.  And spending time with this soulmate of mine--I have to tell you--she's been THE BEST THING IN MY ENTIRE LIFE.  But... when the Covid19 thing happened... she went into a dark, dark, deep, deep place.  And she pushed me so far away that... now... we're separated.  Probably "over".  100%.  She was also my BEST friend.  And I mean it... my BEST friend.  :( :( :(  And now... she doesn't want to talk to me... doesn't care about me.  Doesn't want to see me.  And now... I feel so abjectly empty.  Worthless (in some ways--although not regarding my work + influence on people's lives in the past).  I can't sleep.  I couldn't eat for a month.  I had to move 500+ miles away.  My life is in a shambles... and not even therapy is helping.  Maybe a little... but... I can't explain it:  I LOST MY SOULMATE TO THESE TERRIBLE DISEASES.  PLEASE seek help as early as you can if signs appear.  Please help FORCE others to seek help if they are avoiding it, preventing it, or worse... enabling others to just sweep the problems under the rug.  My "life"... what I had... my DREAM... my happiness--these were all forfeit.  I now simply... "exist".  I pray that you NEVER have to endure what I am enduring right now.  It's only a piece of the puzzle of problems, but... omg... please--pray that you never end up like me.  I just wish I never lost this sweet, amazing, talented, beautiful soul... to these terrible, demonic diseases.  :(
author: No one star

text: I was really hoping that this movie would focus on Fred Rogers and his life in television: how he got into the business, how his children's show was developed, etc. Looks like it is about a journalist who has father issues, and how Rogers helps the guy work things out. That's nice, but Fred deserves a film that concentrates on his accomplishments in children's television. He is without question a legend and an icon whose gifts and contributions to society can't be underestimated. He touched the lives of so many children, and gave them worth and truth and kindness.

author: Jimmy Figueras

text: Unpopular opinion, but I personally would've given Tom Hanks the Oscar for Best Supporting Actor.  Hanks took a well-known icon of the best humanity has to offer, and he made him human. In a way, it's also a meta commentary on how we view Tom Hanks, who is also considered one of the nicest celebrities of all time. Just like how he portrays Mr. Rogers, the film reminds us that Hanks, too, is only human, and one day he will pass like Fred did. But what's most important is we honor both men's legacies by spreading their message of kindness and acceptance across the world.  (Has absolutely nothing to do with Brad's performance. It's just my personal preference.)
author: Juno Keira Page

text: The movie won‚Äôt do well outside of the US. We never got Fred in the UK until the miracle of YouTube, and being from Scotland I never even heard of him until a Canadian friend of mine put me onto his show, and I swear seeing that show was the best thing that ever happened to me. At that time I was battling drug addiction and depression and thanks to Fred I beat one of them. I watch reruns of the show all the time and it does help me with my depression even though I still have good days and bad days.  I try to follow his example and be a good person and even though it‚Äôs difficult as people are dickheads. I can say I wake up most mornings with a smile and most nights I go to bed with a smile thanks to Fred. He was the sweetest, kindest most gentle of people and his words really got me through the worst period of my life. I think he saved my life actually. God bless that man. I‚Äôll be going to see that movie and it‚Äôs a shame I‚Äôll probably be the only person in the theatre.

text: I never grew up with Mr. Rodgers but I've heard a lot of wonderful things about him and the things people say about him at first I was skeptical but the more I learned about him through the people who knew or met him... the more I felt ashamed for doubting. No one had said a single bad thing about him he made it impossible to hate him. And in all honesty I wanted to try and emulate him but the life I live I'm quick to anger and bottle it up before exploding, I argue about and against everything people tell me to do, and no matter what I try I cant find that kindness in me that Mr. Rodgers tries to share with everyone.  But I think we should all try to be like Mr. Rodgers not just the millenials or the boomers but all of us. The world needs someone like Mr. Rodgers who gives kindness for the sake of kindness.  This post may vanish but I hope those who see it try to be more like this man who gives kindness to even the worse of us even when we dont deserve it.

text: I just saw the movie a few hours ago, and this trailer is *very misleading.*   I thought it was going to be a sappy ‚ÄúOscar Bait‚Äù movie (since it came out on November 22nd, aka ‚ÄúOscar season‚Äù and the music in the trailer is very ‚Äúuplifting‚Äù) BUT it wasn‚Äôt.   Sure it‚Äôs got happy moments and you do learn some wonderful life lessons from Mr. Rogers, but it‚Äôs very slow, serious, and even dark at times.   It doesn‚Äôt feel manipulative (for the most part!) nor does it feel like the film is trying so hard to win Oscars despite being a biopic starring Tom Hanks.

Saturday‚Äôs and Sunday‚Äôs I‚Äôd go to my Pap‚Äôs house when I was really young. He lived about an hour away. He would always put Mr. Rogers neighborhood on in the mornings. I didn‚Äôt understand most things he said. However, when I did start to get older and understand, I learned a lot. I learned things that schools can‚Äôt teach a child. Though I never met Mr. Rogers (I say this cause I live in Pittsburgh) I still feel to this day that through his show I knew him so well...   Rest In Peace, neighbor.

text: Hardly anyone knows that Fred Rogers, Bob Keeshan (Captain Kangaroo) and ‚ÄúBuffalo Bob‚Äù Smith (Howdy Doody Show) were all combat decorated heroes of World War Two. Rogers was a Marine sniper, Keeshan was a PT Boat Skipper and Smith was a D-Day paratrooper in the famous ‚ÄúEasy Company‚Äù. RIP, Heroes. Mister Rogers is credited with 15 Japanese killed. He seldom talked about it unless he was stoned out of his gourd on peyote and tequila. He said the phrase ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a beautiful day in the neighborhood‚Äù was just something he said every time he killed a Japanese.

text: I wish people would stop calling this a biography, because it's not. The story is very loosely based on a magazine article by Tom Junod, but in the movie we have the fictional character Lloyd Vogel. Almost nothing of Vogel's story actually happened to Junod. It is a work of fiction and Lloyd Vogel is a fictional character. Which means that the "Mr. Rogers" in the film is also a fictional character. He may have said and done somewhat similar things with somebody at some time, but it wasn't with Lloyd Vogel, because he doesn't exist.  I just find it very presumptuous for the director and screenwriters to appropriate the reputation of Fred Rogers and use him as a character in a fictional story and then pretend this tells us anything at all about the real person.
author: Terry Donnelly

text: Fun Fact: The last scene of the people on the subway singing the theme song actually happened in real life. He was in New York City and he couldn't find a taxi so he went on the subway. He was trying to not get any attention from anyone. There was a diverse crowd and school children. They didn't ask for an autograph or anything, they just sang. That's how wholesome Mr. Rogers is. ( edit: everyone in the comments saying obviously that happened because it‚Äôs a biopic about him, well some biopics exaggerate the story, while this is genuine)

text: I grew up in the early 80's and I can still remember watching Captain Kangaroo and Mister Rogers. I'm telling you childhood for a kid didn't get better than that. You can't explain it to kids now, they won't ever know what it was like to have that time. You didn't get reruns over and over, none of us had VCR's. You saw it that one time during the day and that was it, and that, and the shows themselves, made it special, and it's not likely to ever come again. But what a simple concept Fred Rogers had, to be decent to each other and to just teach kids without any angles, sides, or bias to one view or another. To him, all the kids were the same, and they were all special.

text: As a child of the 70s I grew up watching Mister Rogers.  We only had two channels, and along with Sesame Street, this was the highlight of my day.  My father, used to think it was funny to CA him "Fairy Rogers" until I ended up in tears.   Not long after, my father would be moving onto his new life and I was one of the many lost and rejected kids of divorce in the 80s.   Seeing this movie makes me realize that my father needed to attack Mister Rogers because he himself was a weak man.  He never had the empathy or caring in him that a Fred Rogers had for others, and that was a threat to him. Now, 40 years later and i remember that, even if I didn't know it at the time, it was Mister Rogers and his telling me my feelings mattered that helped me through all of that, and made me into the father I try to be for my daughter, whose emotions always matter to me.  Thank Mister Rogers.
author: Chris Neilson

I believe Fred Rogers didn't have one unkind bone in his body, he loved everyone and treated everyone like they were his best friend, such a beautiful soul, an angel sent from heaven above, so sad he's no longer here to see the impact of his legacy, may he rest in peace <3 Xxxx

text: There was this wimpy little man on PBS, gentle and quiet. Mr. Rogers is another of those you would least suspect of being anything but what he portrayed. But Mr. Rogers was a U.S. Navy Seal, combat-proven in Vietnam with over twenty-five confirmed kills to his name. He wore a long-sleeve sweater to cover the many tattoos on his forearm and biceps. (He was) a master in small arms and hand-to-hand combat, able to disarm or kill in a heartbeat. He hid that away and won our hearts with his quiet wit and charm.

text: I didn't watch much of Mr Roger's show growing up, but my autistic daughter loves, loves, loves Daniel Tiger's Neighborhood. And, after seeing this trailer I can confidently say that Mr Rogers  is truly an amazing motivator of positive things. Nevermind what he's done for so-called "normal" people, but the fact that his legacy still reaches, and connects with different types of people (like my non-verbal daughter), is a testament to the power of caring, and love, and acceptance and understanding. And in a troubled world like today, we could all use a safe and genuine reminder of what  it means to be human.  Thanks Mr Rogers, for being, "different"...  (ps, re-evaluate what it should mean to be a celebrity [and celbritism])

She screamed for mom. And was walking funny. Grandma ignored it and we left. Grandma tried changing sisters diaper she refused to let Grandma changed her. Mom arrived later that night. Mom asked what happend. Grandma lied states in she fell. We got in the car mom looks at me and the other 2. Which I am the oldest. I said we went to see Fred Rogers the Mister Rogers Neighborhood Star. Mom's eyes got big dad slammed on the brakes and goes DO WHAT!! He turns and floors it back to Grandma's house. Before Grandma opens the door my mom attacks her. My sister said that Fred Rogers touched and rubbed her private part. We tried suing police department was like laughing. text: I (with my family) owned a few bars, and lounges in NYC. Everyday at 5/6pm we would play a Johnny Costa jazz version of ‚ÄòWont you be my neighbor‚Äô. It always fit in well with the ambiance; and never failed to make the entire room smile. It was a message from us to them: although they‚Äôre adults now, discussing business in a cutthroat world- they still need to be a neighbor to another, and allow another to be a neighbor to them. This went on for 20 years or so. One day in 2013 I sat at the bar while this song played, and nobody noticed it. It saddened me, because I know that in these times we needed Mr Rogers the most. In these times we all are in desperate need of a neighbor. The song no longer plays in our bars and lounges. But I encourage to let someone be a neighbor to you, and you in turn be a neighbor to someone else. You may not feel like much, but to someone who needs a friendly word, you can literally be the difference between life and death.
author: David Hues

text: Tom Hanks is perfect to play Mr. Rogers. I would see such movie based on that. This trailer seems like the movie will focus on a sub character who I am guessing is Mr. Rogers's publicist/promoter. This character (who I am not sure if they are an existing person) seems like he is meant to be us, the viewer as a character in the movie and we are supposed to experience the greatness of Mr. Rogers's through him. This character will probably go through some struggle in life and Mr. Rogers will provide him the positive influence to carry through. This will be meant to help us face our own struggles in life. People will watch the movie though and say  "who was that guy? I wanted see Mr. Rogers". I hope I'm wrong though. Mr. Rogers was such an awesome guy and people should be able to experience that without any intervention.   What is really sad is that Mr. Rogers is gone and all we got was a cartoon cat to replace him. üòî

text: If you're furious about Climate Change Crisis and want to do something that takes less than five minutes?  Contact/email your local representatives to: - Refuse donations/investments from major oil and fossil fuel industries in politics. - Support your local working community, municipalities, healthcare and education - Reform and regulate product waste from industries that exploit lax environmental laws. - Ban non-reusable plastics from our products and subsidize bio-degradable packaging - Grant benefits on zero waste energy programs and products - Improve on recycling facilities and employment - Invest in reforestation and sustainable agriculture programs - Encourage local farms and community-based agriculture jobs. - Redistribute the wealth of elite billion-dollar industries back into countries and environments that they've exploited over the generations. Hold them culpable.  On an individual scale, you can also; - Donate to environmentalist lobbies - contact your local reps and news stations to address climate change. - Buy localized products - Avoid products (if possible) that have direct ties with perpetuating unfair working conditions and disregard for environmental regulation. - Take public transit more often - Eat less meat - Talk about it, stop cowering about it.  I know there's plenty more things to do. This is just a bare minimal. Unite against apathetic corporate obstruction. Fight for our future.

text: I have been debating weather or not I should comment on this trailer....  I was a child of the ‚Äò80s and I remember watching Mr. Rodgers when I was very small...I remember it feeling VERY CREEPY and as I got older and had more ‚Äúlife experience‚Äù (ya know...as a kid HA) I couldn‚Äôt even bare to even click through channels in case I would see even a part of that show because it just set off alarms in my head that something was SERIOUSLY wrong with this guy.... Later on in my childhood I began to have the literally UNCANNY ability to spot people in our communities who were quite literally pedophile of the worst sort...though a pedophile of any sort is the worst sort if you ask me..... I‚Äôve always been one of those people who can spot ‚ÄúTHEM‚Äù even in my own family!  Looking back on that show I watching in early childhood I finally understood what I had been feeling...what those ALARM bells in my head actually meant!    In my experience there is NO ONE on the face of this earth who can ‚Äòact‚Äô as kindhearted, people caring, and a ‚Äòlover‚Äô of all individuals and NOT be a complete and total fraud!    Though I guess something in his past could have happened to give him some kind of bran damage....Or some kind of malformation of the brain at birth that can create a demeanor he seemed to have had..... There has to be a reason Tom Hanks is pulling from his character ‚ÄúForest Gump 1994‚Äù. LOL It will be interesting to see this just to see how bad it is and if there are no ‚Äòdirty little secrets‚Äô then this ‚Äúneighbor‚Äù is a COMPLETE fabrication of the studios who created this movie.... because, aint NOBODY that nice/kind/caring on the face of our planet!

text: I messed up today. I went online and went about petty arguments with hate in my heart. Though I did not grow up watching his show, I have been kind of researching Mr. Rogers' life.  It makes my angry mean spirited bullshit seem all the more ruinous and horrible.    I feel a bit inspired to really react with compassion the next time I find myself in a political or philosophical argument.  We are currently so historically divided into isolated pockets of dislike for one another; and the answer isn't to simply "not talk politics and religion at the dinner table". No. We need to learn how to discuss these topics with kindness toward eachother. Imagine what might be accomplished if we as a species truly learned this as an ingrained instinct?

text: Tom Hanks has been my favourite actor since the 90s but something feels off with his portrayal of Mr. Rogers - almost like he is playing a caricature of him.   Maybe it‚Äôs just impossible to capture the the look and feel of Fred Rogers. Behind his eyes, smile and of each movement and sound uttered from his mouth, there‚Äôs no sense of mistrust or ill-will - just genuine care.  It‚Äôs the same as someone never being able to play your parents. Something is just missing, at no fault of the actor.   Regardless, if anyone were to play Mr. Rogers, Tom Hanks would the best choice.   I guess Mr. Rogers just means that much to those of us that have grown up with him.
author: Pika817

text: Sorry I want to like Mr. Rogers, he obviously was a nice man, but his persona gave me the creeps as a kid. An old slender sweater wearing man who wants me to come to his house. text: I would love to see this movie. The Mister Rogers documentary from last year was so great it was almost overwhelming. But I can't deal with the insane hype machine for this relentlessly mediocre actor that's been going on for 30 years now. Every Tom Hanks movie becomes a celebration of Tom Hanks, not the subject matter or the people he plays. Even little things, like phoning it in on Fred Rogers' distinctive, world-famous, accent, and the fact (which I learned from the documentary) that Rogers was obsessive about keeping his weight at 143 lbs--a response to his childhood obesity, and a personal reminder of the words "I (1) LOVE (4) YOU (3)." Hanks is easily 80 pounds over that. Not a sin, but there are at least 100 great actors who could have done this role better, and the public's love of Mr. Rogers would have sold it without this guy who's more a self-important star-tripping Oscar-seeker than an actor. The cult of Tom Hanks and Tom Cruise just rankles me.
author: Sean Rockwell

text: Speaking as a Brit with no prior knowledge of your Mister Rogers many would say I'm not really qualified to comment. I have been watching various videos though so I totally understand how much of an impact this man had on generations of children. I've read much criticism of the decision to cast Tom Hanks in the role,and some criticism of the voice/accent. My opinion is that he is a perfect choice from what I have seen. I don't think he is trying to impersonate the person,I take it to be more of a portrayal of the essence of the man and that's obviously a tough challenge.He's certainly sold it to me! For the movie to be successful outside the States,I think it had to be a big name actor for it to draw people in. I will certainly go to see this movie and hope it does well. If the movie and actors win awards,that would be wonderful,but the trailer deserves recognition in its own right at the Trailer Awards.

text: Is it weird that (the real) Mr. Rogers reminds me of my grandma? She grew up in Pittsburgh, PA and her voice had the same accent/timbre as Mr. Rogers' voice had. She also had short, grey hair. She loved to knit and once she made me a sweater very much like the ones Mr. Rogers wore (that I sadly outgrew all too quickly, but I still have it). And she had a bunch of books of classic stories, fairy tales, fantasy novels like Lord Of The Rings, etc. , kind of like Mr. Rogers with the Neighborhood Of Make-Believe. RIP Grandma (1916-2012).

text: Dear Sony Pictures, I hope the proceeds from this motion picture does not go to line the pockets of the greedy. Mr. Rogers was a man of virtue, he refused to let his face be used for anything that would be considered unwholesome. he refused Burger King when the used him in advertising without his permission, all he did was ask the CEO to apologies and remove the ad. He didn't sue them, he didn't ask for compensation, he didn't even condemn. He got ahold of the owners and told them why he didn't like what they did. He did so many things for children and he would still be today. If a life is only worth the amount of money it can make then it isn't a life at all. Every life is special and no one deserves to be better off than the ones who are underfoot.

text: Nice try by Hanks, but as the old saying goes, the eyes are the window to the soul. Hanks eyes reveal the hate, disdain and cold harshness typical of the soul of a modern Urban Progressive Lib elite. Can't hide that, no matter how much makeup is used. He is also has an abruptness in his attempt to duplicate Rogers speech mannerisms. I always thought that Rogers deserved a movie or documentary created in his honor, but they could have chosen an actor, even an unknown that would better fit the part. I really have to watch and fact-check this movie, because Hollywood always adds their own tilt to the point of a total warp of the truth. Well, at least they did not cast Rogers wearing lipstick, a skirt and bra. Nice attempt, but this movie could have been a classic masterpiece if they just stayed away from using Hanks in the lead role.

text: Mr. Rogers, although held as the most influential children's television personality in TV history,  had one major flaw. He turned an entire generation of Americans into blubbering cry babies. Yes, I said it. You are not special. The world will continue to spin after you die. Nobody owes you jack squat. Be kind, of course. Be real, be respectful. But tell the truth. Nobody likes the truth. The world is a horrible place. Stop crying and be a mensch. In the eyes of the creator you are special, but there is no such thing as a free lunch...I wish Mr.Rogers revealed that to us more than "You're so special". It created our entitlement legacy we have to deal with now...

text: One day in the early afternoon I came home from a business trip. Coming thru the front door my wife greeted me with her index finger on her lips, a signal of "shush". She quietly took my hand and walked me over to the doorway of the family room. There I saw ten "munchkins", ages 2 to 7 years, absolutely enthralled and transfixed watching the TV. Each had their own bowl of melon fruit, and were eating without taking their eyes off of the TV. My wife had an after school day care she ran out of our house. Along with our two small boys at this time she on and off watch 6-8 neighborhood kids ages 5-8 years old.  I asked her what they were watching and she said this new show called "Mr Rodgers Neighborhood". I sat down at the dining room table to watch the show, my wife brought me a bowl of fruit, and we watched the show with the kids. Not one word was said. We just sat and enjoyed the show. What a great afternoon! Now my boys are grown men with families of their own and have moved out of state for better job opportunities and affordable houses, the neighborhood kids are grown and also moved away, and my wife pass 13 years ago.  Yet I've made new friends with the new neighbors and their kids. They're a more modern family, don't watch much TV, everything is the internet and their cell phones. I don't blame them though with all the crap on TV these days.   It's just too bad they don't have a Mr Rodgers TV show to watch together after school!  üòâ

text: One of the single most important people of my childhood right behind my parents was Fred Rogers. His kindness, his teachings, his legacy lives on in many of us. One of the most shocking moments of my life was hearing about his passing in 2003. I remember every detail about where I was and who I was with. Only two other deaths effected me as much as to be burned into my memory. My grandmother (maternal) and my father. That‚Äôs how important Fred Rogers was to me. This movie has generations riding on it. And I must say it looks very promising. Tom Hanks was the right choice.

text: Looks like another addition to a great season of biopics. I would very much like Hollywood to do one  on Jared Fogle, the former Subway spokesperson and now convicted felon,  roly-poly-boy-toy and daily punching bag for any number of his fellow inmates at the federal penitentiary in Englewood, Colorado.   Perhaps it could be a musical.   One of the numbers could be called "Smaller Pants," and two different versions could both open and close the production.  In the beginning, Jared sings "I wanna get in smaller pants," in reference to his desire to lose weight by eating only veggie subs.  At the end prior to his arrest, as he's flying around the country molesting children, he could sing the same line, but it would of course have a far more sinister meaning.   Another number could involve a couple of parents going to the authorities to report that their pre-adolescent son has been victimized by Fogle.  The song could be titled "He Went to Jared."   You see, I'm a dead ringer for Fogle.   We're talking "separated at birth" identical.   Up until November, 2015 I had a fairly steady part time gig posing as him and entertaining at kids' birthday parties.  For a reasonable fee, I'd provide the entertainment (balloon animals and showing the kids the former pants with a 48 inch waistline that "Jared" used to have to wear before he started eating Subway veggies subs everyday) and the food (a Subway platter). Needless to say, my tax returns for the past few years have shown a fairly significant reduction in income. My last gig was just after Thanksgiving in 2015. The people who had booked me had paid a deposit in advance, so they went ahead and had me come out with my balloons and five foot cold cut with six toppings on  Italian herb bread.  I ended up getting mauled by their German Shepherd who had been watching CNN a week or so earlier.

text: I had the great honor of meeting Mister Rogers at the US Airways Club in Pittsburgh just months before his death and before his fatal illness was made public.  He was flying to meet his wife at their home in Nantucket and when I went to introduce myself and shake his hand I found myself with tears in my eyes.  He asked me to sit with him and talk for a while.   We discussed my kids and his home in Nantucket and I felt like I was with a man that embodied pure and total kindness.   I have had the honor to meet Presidents and Kings in my life but there is no greater honor and experience than my meeting Mister Rogers for those 15 mins at the Airport in Pittsburgh.    Both of our home neighborhoods :-)
author: Randy Frasinelli

text: This trailer for the new Tom Hanks movie about Mr. Rogers is so full of Mandela Effect madness I can hardly contain myself! Do you remember "it's a beautiful day in THE neighborhood' or "it's a beautiful day in THIS neighborhood"? The title of the film is the lyric line I remember Mr. Rogers singing at the top of every Neighborhood show (and apparently from the footage shown here in the trailer, what his fans on the subway remember as well). However, what Mr. Rogers sings in the current reality has changed from what many of us so fondly remember from childhood.
author: Nathan Sanders

text: Mr Rogers was about respecting and loving everybody equally, just as they were. He wouldn‚Äôt have cared if they were Democratic or Republican, or what their nationality was.  The truth is that this is a movie about the most loving man you could think of. People now are starting fights with one another for the most irrelevant things that don‚Äôt matter.   Mr. Rogers would probably be disappointed to see America in its current state. He wouldn‚Äôt be mad. He wouldn‚Äôt be upset. He would just be disappointed. So much anger and hate. From both sides. I feel like we‚Äôve all let Mr. Rogers down.  Mr Rogers, the world needs you more than ever right now.

text: I‚Äôm literally in tears right now after watching this video.   He‚Äôs my hero.   I had a somewhat traumatic childhood: going through my parents violent divorce, being raised in a highly controlling religious family, being a victim of child abuse.  During all of that, Mr. Rogers was there for me; everyday after school affirming my worth and dignity, giving me a model of unconditional love and positivity, and emotional vulnerability, and providing stability.   I ‚ù§Ô∏è  Mr. Rogers.   IMHO Mr. Rogers was a modern saint.

text: I've already teared up from this.  I don't know if I can watch the movie comfortably besides on my basement TV, on the downstairs couch, with three blankets, a six pack of Iron City, and soaking up sad/nostalgic tears with my terrible towel. It will be tough..  But really, Fred Rogers is even more special to me as a 35 year old.  He told the viewing children (but I always felt like he was speaking to me) that I was special.  I believed him then, and today I realize that HE made my adult life better. Because when I was young, there was a wonderful, approachable adult on tv (cartoon= not real) whom consistently explaining hard topics, with grace and understanding and with compassion to how the adult world scares children. To me, Fred was a counselor, a comfort, an adult that was encouraging, an adult that was understanding, and an adult that was there for me unconditionally.  I loved him back then, I love and am grateful for him now.
author: Laz s

text: We all knew it‚Äôs: ‚ÄúA beautiful day in THE neighborhood‚Äù NOT ‚ÄúA beautiful day in MY neighborhood‚Äù they call it ‚ÄúThe Mandela effect‚Äù We (most) remember it as ‚ÄúThe‚Äù not ‚ÄúMy‚Äù CRAZY!! I‚Äôm glad this movie at least mixes it up, and uses both versions lol..before anyone decides to comment, I suggest at least YouTubing all the videos on this subject.. also speaking of Tom Hanks: if you do research this, you will also most likely come across the same thing, but in the Forest Gump movie. Talking about the famous quote in there ‚Äú momma says life is like a box of chocolates you never know what you‚Äôre going to get‚Äù and then the actual quote that‚Äôs in the movie, but we (most) remember it being said just like I quoted? The list goes on, and on, but about a bunch of other famous quotes that ‚Äúhave changed‚Äù but most remember it a certain way.. Just like ‚ÄúLuke I am your father‚Äù now for some reason.. turns out that quote was NEVER actually said in Star Wars!?!? Like WTH!? If you have read this far in my comment, then ya really have to do the research. It‚Äôs pretty strange. Thanks.

text: In a time that I had no one.....my mother chasing men, my father in the Navy and never wrote or called and an abusive older brother.....he made me feel safe and cared for. He was so gentle that I almost hated him at times because he wasn't "real"....he was just someone on the t.v. Other times, it was the only calming voice I ever heard and that it was ok to feel sad and cry. It was normal, no matter what I was being told by "family". The man probably saved many lives by just being him.

text: Mr. Rogers was the epitome of kindness that every child needed in their life. He taught us how to deal with strong emotions, he taught us about evil and violence and how to deal with seeing it. He always truly cared about every single child, even if he never met them.   I will always remember one line in the show that he said:   ‚ÄúYou are a very special person. There is only one like you in the whole world. There's never been anyone exactly like you before, and there will never be again. Only you. And people can like you exactly as you are.‚Äù  Thank you Mr. Rogers for teaching me that self worth was more important than anything and showing care for everyone, especially a child, is the best thing we could do for society. I think this generation really needs to watch you. It‚Äôs not just a show for children but for everyone. ‚ù§Ô∏è

text: I saw Mr. Rogers in person at this one local event and what I saw made me love him even more. Here he was doing a short of "Live" show when this kid in a wheelchair comes into this hall we were all in. Mr. Rogers himself noticed that the mother of that child was looking for a place so they could watch the performance. Mr. Rogers then came off the stage and personally pushed that wheelchair on the stage and had the mother sitting next to her child and they watched the show there. Even getting to meet everyone, and seeing and touching the puppets. It is something I will never forget. Mr. Rogers will always be very special to me no matter how old I live, I will never forget him...ever.

text: They will never know. The Kids today will never know what it was like to have him. We used to watch Mr. Rogers when we were in the dark. When we hid from the evil's of the world, we had him. And we were happy. We were happy because he was there when we needed him. When we were afraid, alone, sad, hurt, angry or lost. We had him. He made us forget the world.  He was our light in this world full of darkness. And now he is dead. But his still with us. We're still here, so his still with us.  He lives on because we remeber him.  And we must pass on his memory to our children & their children's children. The kids today will never know. P.s. All those who disliked this is part of the darkness that has infected this world. You people that disliked this are lost & will never be found.

text: Something I never considered: Mr. Rogers meeting fans on the street. Just, weird to consider. Him existing like anyone else, putting his pants on one leg at a time. I didn't grow up with him, but he always existed as background radiation to my life. He was always this monolithic figure, of pure goodness and joy. But the image of him awkwardly meeting fans on the street just feels so bizarrely human.

text: I can tell you probably my favorite story about Mr. Rogers: that he could make a whole New York City subway car full of strangers sing. text: I think what touches me most about Fred Rogers is that after all these years we found nothing in his past, about his life, that ever contradicted what we saw in the man on TV. He was just as sweet and thoughtful and kind in his personal life to everyone he knew as he was on television and for that, in this day and age of Cosby and other fallen legands, I cannot thank him enough.   He is truly an icon and one of the last remaining respectable figures we can ALL look up to and feel hope in humanity again.

text: I was born in 2002, and while that wasn‚Äôt a direct reason, I never really watched Mr. Rogers‚Äô Neighborhood. I just never knew it existed and didn‚Äôt get around to it. Even then, when I first learned about Mr. Rogers a year ago I was fascinated with him as a human being. Such a kind and gentle soul has never graced this earth (well except for Jesus as I believe in him but I understand not everyone does). He was a true example of what it means to be Christian. He didn‚Äôt shove his opinions on people and he truly cared for the mental health and well being of children.  I have never so much in my life desires to have grown up watching this show, but at least now I can enjoy what I can from the internet.

text: What I remember from my childhood memories in the early 80‚Äôs was, sitting very early in the morning in front of our tv üì∫, before anything would broadcast, just staring at a screen with no image. Just black and white distortion and noise until the American flag üá∫üá∏ would show followed by the Star Spangled Banner and then all the best shows and cartoons would roll throughout the whole day. Within those special shows that taught me so much,  Mr. Rogers was in my  top 10 favorites . Sesame Street, He-Man, Hanna-Barbera toons, ThunderCats, MASK, Knight Rider, Air Wolf, Smurfs, The A Team, The Chipmunks and many many more! Thank you Mr. Roger, for memories and life lessons that I will hold dearly to my heart. Thanks to Sony for choosing such a talented, respected and honorable man like Tom Hanks for this roll. Can‚Äôt wait to bring my kids to watch this in the theaters!

I used to get bullied in high school for being from Pittsburgh (had moved to another part of the country) to the point that I had lost interest in the sports teams I had grown up with. Seeing this trailer has actually reminded me of what a great city I grew up in and how much I love it. I constantly had people saying "Pittsburgh sucks" right to my face, but Pittsburgh doesn't suck. text: I grew up watching Mister Rogers' Neighborhood and I am happy to see that there is a biopic being made about Fred Rogers.  Fred Rogers was a unique individual who cared about children and their early education. I like how he calmly and warmly addressed the television audience in each episode of Mister Rogers' Neighborhood and how he accepted everyone just the way they were. There will never be another person like Fred Rogers.  I am looking very forward to seeing this movie when it is released in November.

text: As a child, I didn't like "Mr. Rogers' Neighborhood". I guess I just found him a little off-putting for no real reason other than he, and the show, just made me feel uncomfortable. The irony is that it wasn't until I was older and well out of the age range of his most loyal viewers that I began to understand what Fred was doing, and I started appreciating the healthy, supportive messages and life lessons he wanted to share with kids as well as adults, and really, there were lessons there for parents as well.... I have a feeling that this is going to be a smash hit, and Hanks seems perfect in this role.  Very interested in seeing this movie.....

text: He was an ordained minister and expressed Christianity in all he did. He was kind to all, especially children. He made each and every person he met feel special. He was constantly alert to the needs of others. He sought out the overlooked and disregarded, which were usually children, but not necessarily due to cruelty, although he must have seen that throughout his life in service to others. Children are usually marginalized due to their size, mental capacity and strength, and because they depend on the kindness of adults to survive. He always raised them in importance and gave them self worth. It was not only out of kindness but with true respect and love for each and every one. While Tom Hanks is an obvious Hollywood choice, there is no one there in today‚Äôs anti Christian bias whom respects the true calling of love and kindness to all mankind a true Christian tries to manifest. It was the heart of Mr Rogers and whom and what he tried and succeeded to express with his life. Each day I entrusted my very young son, his heart and mind mostly an empty slate to this man whom I really did not know. I watched carefully as he filled his slate with dignity, security and knowledge. Most of all it was filled with kindness and respect for others and then I relaxed. My son was safe with Mr Rogers. I also saw how much my son loved Mr Rogers and it was because Mr Rogers loved him, and somehow through a box with a glass window, my son knew it.
author: SD

text: I wish children's television still had that attention to showing empathy to children and their issues. One thing that always struck with me was that he never belittled children. He always reminded viewers that to a child they need attention, empathy, love in everything they experience be it from learning to tie their shoes, brushing their teeth, and life events (like the jfk assassination, divorce etc).  If anything I remember reading about the man who did the documentary who went in with one intent, with digging the truth and coming out to ending his documentary remembering one person who helped him in his career: his mom. That's what is Mr Rogers ultimate influence. He turned a possible realist maybe cynic into a believer of love, compassion and empathy.

text: This is my Most Anticipated Film of the Year! I've been looking forward to it ever since it was first announced! "Mister Rogers' Neighborhood" was among the variety of shows I watched as a kid. He is, without a doubt, one of the best TV show hosts of all time! Mr. Rogers knew how to treat his audience like people and present his topics in that manor! I very much enjoyed the "Won't You Be My Neighbor" Documentary as well! (I will never know or understand why it didn't get an Oscar nomination for Best Documentary Feature at the Academy Awards!) Tom Hanks, the nicest guy in Hollywood, and one of my absolute favourite actors of all time, was born to play Mr. Rogers! Many thanks to Mr. Rogers, Tom Hanks, Sony Pictures, and all the other key people behind this movie! I absolutely cannot wait to see it! (And actually, I'll take my parents out to see it, as a gift for their Anniversary this year!)
author: Joshua Giraffe

text: I had a neighbor, Mr. Elden. He was super old (I was ten) and he was the sweetest guy. Being a dumb kid, I would scramble over the fence into his yard to eat his yummy strawberries. He caught me once, and I panicked, could not get up the fence.  He led me through his garage, to get back, and there I made an amazing discovery... He had taken in every stray cat in our neighborhood, and half of them had kittens. There must have been 25 kittens in there! Within seconds, I sat down and been swarmed by their little meowing poof balls. Every color, kind, and age, down to little itty bitty kitties, just all over me wanting love.  It was one of the best moments of my childhood. But the best part, was getting to knock on his door every day, and go back to garage with my little brother to pet the kitties. He would bring over baskets of berries and homemade jams. It was a light, in a dark time. Thank you Mr. Elden, RIP.

text: Several major news outlets in the United Kingdom recently published articles or produced programs calling for an end to the killing of prisoners of conscience for organs in China, including the BBC, The Guardian, Sunday Express, and Scotsman.    A discussion titled ‚ÄúForced Live Organ Extraction in China‚Äù took place at the British House of Parliament on March 26, 2019, offering media a timely news hook to delve into the issue. Hosted by MP Jim Shannon, chair of the all-party parliamentary group on freedom of religion and belief, 12 parliament members from a number of different political parties joined the discussion, voicing their outrage and concern over the state-sanctioned crimes of forced organ harvesting in China. BBC Radio 4 covered this event with a segment that was aired the following day during its ‚ÄúYesterday in Parliament‚Äù program.

text: I have to see this as soon as it comes out in theaters.  I just hope I can keep my composure in the theater.  Tom Hanks has portrayed several real to life individuals, but I hope this one he does his best performance ever.  Unlike any other person he has portrayed, Mr. Rogers was someone that was a part of our lives and a member of our families.  We grew up with him, the world was a more beautiful place when he was here, and when he left, he took a piece of all of us with him.  RIP Mr. Rogers, if he were here today, I would hope he would approve of this.

text: I guess I have to be that guy: why do we need this movie?  I love Mister Rodgers and he should get as much publicity as possible, but aren't there already plenty of actual documentaries? Between interviews with him, his speeches, and the actual show being easy to find,  why do we need a re-enactment?  This just feels like, and probably is, a cash grab off of a great figure.  Now, if all profits went directly to charity that would be a much different story, and I'd happily put out $10 for it.  Otherwise, I don't think he would honestly approve of this movie.

This makes him a true hero.  When I herd that they were going to make a movie, I was so worried that it was going to parody him.  This trailer does not seem to support that worry. text: I want to see that movie with Tom Hanks, where Mr. Rogers gets stranded at an airport on an island with a dog that chews up everything so builds an amusement park in a volcano.  Then he just keeps running around trying to solve an ancient secret code till he finds a Zoltar machine, makes a wish and a magic train comes to take him to the North Pole, on the moon, to meet a Space Man who is actually Santa Claus.  The two become real bosom buddies until he falls in love with a mermaid named Jenny from Seattle who plays in an all-female baseball team.  He works odd-jobs as a prison guard, detective, soldier and sea captain until building a bookstore empire.
